msItem.title: Commissio egregiorum et nobilium virorum dominorum Andree Barbaro et Jacobi Michael, honorabilium sindicorum insule Crete.

argument.p: This manuscript contains the ducal commission issued by Doge Michele Steno appointing Andrea Barbaro and Jacopo Michiel as Sindici Inquisitori for the island of Crete. It preserves the text detailing their mandate to investigate administrative and financial misconduct by Venetian officials, to receive complaints, gather testimony, and enforce restitution where appropriate. The document, as transmitted in this witness, reflects the mechanisms through which the Venetian government supervised and disciplined its officials in the overseas dominion of Crete.

projectDesc.p: This digital scholarly edition provides a semi-diplomatic transcription and structured TEI encoding of the ducal commission of 1408, preserved in two manuscript witnesses. The project aims to model the linguistic, documentary, and administrative characteristics of the original sources in a machine-readable form, enabling further palaeographic, historical, and prosopographical research.

editorialDecl.p: The transcription follows a semi-diplomatic method grounded in direct examination of the manuscripts. Orthography, word division, scribal habits, and the formal structure of chancery Latin have been preserved. Page and line breaks, rubrication, and internal chapter divisions are retained to mirror the documentary layout. Capitalization has been regularised, restricting capital letters to proper nouns (persons, places, and peoples), and punctuation has been standardised to facilitate reading while maintaining the text’s original rhythm.

normalization.p: Orthographic normalization has been deliberately limited. Original spellings (e.g., Corphoy, offitialis, havere, comune) are reproduced. The fluctuating use of u/v and i/j has been left largely unchanged, except where minimal harmonisation was necessary for internal consistency. Scribal abbreviations and suspensions have been silently expanded to improve readability, following conventions used in comparable Digital Scholarly Editions of Venetian documents. No modernization of vocabulary or syntax has been applied.

punctuation.p: Punctuation has been partially standardised to enhance legibility but remains close to the manuscript usage. No modern quotation marks have been added, and no editorial punctuation has been introduced except where required for minimal clarity.

quotation.p: The manuscripts do not employ quotation marks, and no quotation conventions have been imposed. Reported or formulaic speech is conveyed solely through context and TEI structural tags rather than typographic quotation.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenation follows the manuscript only in the ASVe witness case. Line-end word breaks are preserved exactly as written; editorial recombination has not been applied. All manuscript line breaks are encoded using <lb/>. The Marciana witness does not present line breaks.

interpretation.p: Named entities (persons, places, institutions, titles, and offices) are identified only when the attribution is unambiguous. Entities are linked through @ref attributes to controlled vocabularies (listPerson, listPlace, listOrg) and, when possible, to external authority files such as VIAF, Wikipedia, GeoNames, and the Getty TGN. Ambiguous or doubtful readings are annotated through TEI uncertainty mechanisms (e.g., <unclear>).

correction.p: Readings rendered uncertain due to ink corrosion, fungal damage, or ambiguous abbreviations, particularly in the Marciana witness, have been transcribed conservatively. Conjectural readings draw primarily on Hopf’s 19th century edition when manuscript evidence is unclear. All corrected or uncertain readings are explicitly marked.

editorialDecl.p: Automated tools such as Transkribus and ChatGPT were used only after the completion of the manual transcription, as auxiliary instruments to verify palaeographic consistency and Latin orthography. All automated suggestions were reviewed and confirmed against the manuscript, and final validation was conducted in collaboration with Professor Alessandra Rizzi.

samplingDecl.p: Both surviving witnesses were fully transcribed. No sampling procedures were applied.

refsDecl.p: Internal references use @xml:id/@ref linking between entities and their definitions in the TEI header. All cross-references follow a consistent, URI-compatible identifier scheme.

org.desc: The Doge was the chief magistrate and symbolic head of the Republic of Venice, serving as both the leader of the state and the personification of its authority. The office was established during the Middle Ages and lasted until 1797. The Doge was elected for life by the Venetian aristocracy through a complex electoral process designed to prevent corruption and concentration of power. Although early Doges held significant political and military authority, over time their powers were severely limited by the Republic’s councils, making the Doge primarily a ceremonial and unifying figure representing the dignity and continuity of Venice.

The Comune di Venezia (Latin: Communis Venetiarum) was the political and fiscal body of the Republic of Venice, representing the collective interests and resources of the state. In chancery language, the term “comune” designated the public treasury and the ensemble of revenues, rights, and properties belonging to the Republic, as distinct from private or patrimonial wealth. References to “rationes communis” in the commission indicate accounts, grain stocks, and other assets administered on behalf of the Venetian state.

The Consiglio dei Rogati, later known as the Senato, was one of the principal governing bodies of the Republic of Venice. Established in the 13th century, it was composed of patricians elected from the Maggior Consiglio and functioned as the Republic’s main deliberative and executive council. The Rogati supervised foreign policy, finance, and administration, often preparing and executing decisions later ratified by the higher councils. Over time, it became the true center of political power in Venice, balancing the authority of the Doge and ensuring the continuity of government.

The Zonta (Latin: Additio, “addition”) was a temporary body of patricians appointed to assist or augment an existing council. In the context of the present document, it refers to the supplementary group added to the Consiglio dei Rogati. These additional members were selected for specific circumstances or periods, providing broader participation and enhanced oversight within the Venetian political system.

The Maggior Consiglio was the supreme legislative body of the Republic of Venice and the cornerstone of its republican constitution. Composed of all adult male members of the Venetian patriciate, it held authority over lawmaking, elections, and the appointment of public officials. Following the Serrata del Maggior Consiglio of 1297, membership became hereditary, consolidating political power within the noble families. The Maggior Consiglio embodied the collective sovereignty of the Venetian aristocracy and served as the ultimate source of legitimacy for all other institutions of the Republic.

The Consiglio dei Quaranta, also known as the Quarantia, was one of the principal governing and judicial bodies of the Republic of Venice. Established in the early 13th century, it originally functioned as a group of forty electors assisting in the election of the Doge but gradually evolved into a central tribunal with both civil and criminal jurisdiction. Over time, it was divided into separate branches such as the Quarantia Criminale and the Quarantia Civile, while retaining important supervisory powers over legislation, finance, and judicial appeals. The Quaranta played a key role in ensuring legal oversight and accountability within the Venetian administrative system, serving as the ultimate court of justice and an essential element of the Republic’s institutional balance.

The Avogadori di Comun were officials of the Republic of Venice, serving a role similar to that of public prosecutors or guardians of legality. They were among the oldest institutions of the Venetian state, and their main duty was to oversee the legality of government actions and the conduct of officials, thereby protecting the Venetian state itself. They had the authority to challenge decisions made by the Senate or other governing bodies if they believed these violated the law or the public interest. In this way, the Avogadori de Comùn acted as guardians of constitutional order and justice in Venice.

The Ufficiali alle Cazude were a fiscal magistracy of the Republic of Venice responsible for the recovery of unpaid public dues such as taxes, levies, and other financial obligations to the state. Established in the mid-fifteenth century, the office was empowered to enforce payment through the sequestration and sale of property belonging to debtors. The officials ensured compliance with fiscal laws and contributed to the stability of the Republic’s financial administration by overseeing the execution of sentences related to tax arrears and public debts.

The Ufficiali alle Rason Vecchie were financial magistrates of the Republic of Venice responsible for auditing and verifying the accounts of officials who had completed their terms of service, particularly those who had governed overseas territories or administered public funds. Their office, located near the Rialto, examined revenues, expenditures, and balances recorded in official registers, ensuring that all monies due to the commune were properly accounted for. Through this system of post-service auditing, the Ufficiali alle Rason Vecchie played a central role in maintaining fiscal transparency and accountability within the Venetian administrative apparatus.

The Consiglieri Ducali were high-ranking patrician magistrates who formed, together with the Doge, the core of the Signoria of Venice. Elected from among the members of the Maggior Consiglio, they sat permanently at the Doge’s side, sharing in the deliberation and approval of governmental acts, ducal letters, and diplomatic and judicial decisions. Their presence limited the Doge’s individual authority, ensuring that executive power was exercised collectively and in accordance with the broader will of the patriciate.

The Sindici Inquisitori were extraordinary magistrates of the Republic of Venice appointed to inspect and audit the conduct of officials serving in the Republic’s overseas dominions (Stato da Mar) and in the mainland territories (Stato da Terra). Their office, usually composed of a group of patricians elected by the Senato, functioned as a mechanism of accountability within the Venetian administrative system. Empowered to examine financial management, judicial decisions, and abuses of authority, the Sindici could summon witnesses, review documents, and impose sanctions or initiate prosecutions before the Avogadori di Comun or the Quarantia.

The term Rettori served as a general designation for the Venetian governors appointed to administer the Republic’s dominions both overseas (Stato da Mar) and on the mainland (Stato da Terra). It encompassed a range of offices combining judicial, administrative, and military authority on behalf of the central government. For reference, the principal high-ranking Venetian officials in office at the time of the 1408 commission included: Girolamo Donà, Capitano of Crete (1408–1411); Roberto Bon, Rettore of Setia (1407–1409); Michele Duodo, Rettore of Rettimo (1407–1409); Giovanni Cappello, Rettore of Canea (1408–1409); Francesco Foscarini, Signore di Notte in Crete (1407–1409); Tommaso Duodo and Vittore Duodo, Giudici of Crete (1407–1408); Domenico Contarini, Bailo of Corfu (1407–1409); Andrea Giustinian, Castellano of Modon (1407–1409); Antonio dalle Boccole, Castellano of Coron (1408–1410); Eustacchio Cocco, Podestà and Capitano of Napoli di Romania (1408–1410); and Francesco Bembo, Bailo of Negroponte (1405–1408), later succeeded by Nicolò Venier di Sergio (1408–1410).

In the administrative vocabulary of the Venetian Republic, the term Officiali referred broadly to local functionaries serving under the authority of the Rettori. It encompassed a wide spectrum of subordinate offices, including Camerari (treasurers), Notai (notaries), Segretari (secretaries), and other clerical or fiscal officers. The frequent formula “rectoribus vel officialibus” found in the commission reflects the hierarchical yet interdependent relationship between governors and their subordinate personnel; the former exercising delegated sovereignty, the latter ensuring its practical implementation at the local level.

The Consiglieri in the Venetian overseas territories were local councillors who assisted the Rettori, the governors representing Venice’s authority in its overseas possessions. Typically two in number, the Consiglieri acted as advisors and as a check on the Rettori’s power, participating in deliberations, financial administration, and judicial decisions. They represented the Republic’s principle of shared governance and oversight, ensuring that no single official exercised authority unchecked. Their presence in major centres such as Crete, Corfu, and Negroponte reflected Venice’s effort to replicate its republican administrative model across the Stato da Mar.

The Capitani in the Venetian overseas territories were high-ranking military and administrative officials responsible for the defence and supervision of key maritime and overseas centres. They commanded naval and land forces, safeguarded trade routes, and coordinated military operations across the Stato da Mar. In major possessions such as Crete, the Capitano also exercised judicial and political authority alongside the Rettori, particularly in matters of security and maritime law. Their role embodied the dual character of Venetian rule overseas, where military command and civil administration were closely intertwined to protect the Republic’s commercial and strategic interests in the eastern Mediterranean.

The Bailo of Negroponte was the Venetian governor and military commander of the island of Negroponte (modern-day Euboea) during the period of Venetian rule. The title combined both civil and military authority, reflecting Venice’s practice of uniting administrative and defensive responsibilities in key overseas territories.

The Consiglieri di Negroponte were Venetian noble officials appointed to assist the Bailo e Capitano di Negroponte in the governance of the island. Typically two in number, they acted as councillors and institutional counterweights, participating in deliberations on administrative, fiscal, and judicial matters. Their role reflected the Republic’s principle of collegial governance and oversight, ensuring that executive authority in this strategically important overseas territory was exercised collectively rather than by a single magistrate.

The Duca di Creta was the highest Venetian official on the island of Crete, serving as both civil governor and military commander. Appointed directly by the Venetian Senato, the Duke represented the authority of the Republic in its largest and most important overseas possession. He presided over the island’s councils, oversaw the Rettori of the Cretan districts, administered justice, and coordinated the defence of the island. Residing in Candia (modern-day Heraklion), the Duca di Creta embodied Venice’s sovereign presence in the eastern Mediterranean and functioned as the central link between the overseas administration and the government of the Republic.

The Camera di Creta was the central financial office of the Venetian administration in Crete. It managed the revenues, expenditures, and fiscal records of the island, ensuring the proper collection of taxes, rents, and customs duties on behalf of the Venetian Republic. The office was supervised by appointed officials, often under the oversight of the Rettori and the Duca di Creta, who were responsible for maintaining detailed account books and forwarding financial reports to Venice. The Camera di Creta thus played a crucial role in integrating Crete’s economy into the broader fiscal network of the Stato da Mar, ensuring transparency and accountability within the local administration.

The Capitano del Golfo was a senior naval commander of the Venetian Republic responsible for overseeing the security of the Gulf of Venice and the main maritime routes of the eastern Adriatic. Often stationed at Corfu, he commanded a squadron of galleys tasked with protecting merchant convoys, combating piracy, and supervising the coastal fortresses and ports under Venetian control. The Capitano del Golfo also held limited administrative and judicial authority in maritime matters, ensuring compliance with Venetian naval laws. His office was essential to maintaining safe navigation and asserting Venice’s maritime dominance across the Adriatic, which was regarded as the “Venetian Gulf.”

The Sopracomito was a Venetian naval officer commanding an individual galley within the Republic’s fleet. Subordinate to higher-ranking officials such as the Capitano del Golfo, the Sopracomito was responsible for the discipline, navigation, and combat readiness of his vessel and crew. His duties included enforcing maritime regulations, overseeing trade or military missions, and ensuring the galley’s provisioning and maintenance. The position required both seafaring expertise and administrative ability, as the Sopracomito represented Venice’s naval authority in the ports and waters of the Stato da Mar.

The Capitani were a category of Venetian naval officers responsible for commanding armed ships within the fleets of the Republic of Venice. In the wider structure of maritime magistratures, the term encompassed both ship captains and superior officers, including the sopracomito, who supervised discipline, navigation, and military readiness aboard galleys and coordinated operations with other units of the fleet.

person.note: Giovanni Emo was a Venetian nobleman appointed as a Sindaco Inquisitore in 1408, overseeing Corfu, Modon, Coron, Napoli di Romania, and Negroponte. The 1408 itinerary instructed Emo and Tron to accompany Nicolò Venier to Negroponte and continue their inspections across the Levante. Unlike his colleagues, Emo’s career was soon overshadowed by scandal. Upon the commissioners’ return to Venice around 1410, the Avogadori del Comun received a denunciation alleging that Emo had been discovered at night concealed beneath the bed of a certain Margarita Palmeria in Modon, with the intention of engaging in illicit relations with Palmeria’s adoptive daughter, Maria. The castellans of Modon and Coron were ordered to investigate the matter, and after due inquiry, the charges were confirmed. On 9 March 1414, Emo was formally condemned to a fine of 100 lire, a sentence which, although modest in financial terms, carried symbolic weight given the dignity of his office.

place.note: Venice, in the early 15th century, was the political and administrative centre of a dominant maritime republic, controlling key trade routes across the Eastern Mediterranean. As the seat of the major councils and the ducal chancery, it was the place where the Sindici Inquisitori received their commission, swore their oath, and to which they were required to return with their findings. Venice thus served both as the point of departure and the final locus of accountability for their mission.

The Doge’s Palace in Venice, the seat of the Doge and central government of the Republic of Venice, located next to St Mark’s Basilica. It is the place where the Sindici received their commission in April 1408 and where they were required to present their findings upon their return.

Corfu, in the early 15th century, was a key Venetian stronghold in the Levante, controlling the maritime routes linking the Adriatic to the Ionian Sea. After more than a century under the Kingdom of Naples, the island was secured by Venice in 1386 amid weakening Angevin authority. Throughout the following centuries it developed into the most important Venetian outpost outside the Adriatic. In 1408 it constituted one of the primary stations of the Sindici Inquisitori assigned to Romania, who were instructed to examine the conduct of local rectors and officials and to collaborate with the local Consiglio in their inquiries.

Modon (modern-day Methoni) was one of the two fortified Venetian strongholds in Morea, acquired in 1209 and thereafter developed into a major commercial and military station controlling the passage between the Ionian and Aegean Seas. In the 1408 commission, Modon appears as the principal stop of the state galley transporting the Sindici inquisitori to the Levante. It was the place where the four officials were instructed to disembark and separate, with one pair proceeding to Crete and the other continuing their itinerary through the possessions of Romania. This role highlights the city's logistical importance within the maritime routes that connected Venice with its overseas dominions.

Coron (modern-day Koroni), together with Modon, formed the strategic pair of Venetian fortresses guarding the southwestern entrance to the Peloponnese and the sea-lanes linking the Ionian and Aegean Seas. In the early 15th century it served as a key military and logistical base, particularly for the provisioning and safe passage of Venetian fleets. The Sindici were instructed to examine the conduct of the local rectorate, to audit fiscal practices connected with maritime traffic and customs revenues, and to ensure that no abuses were committed in matters affecting naval supply, trade supervision, or the rights of local inhabitants.

Crete, in the early 15th century, was Venice’s most valuable overseas possession, serving as a key hub for trade between Europe, Asia, and North Africa. Its agricultural wealth, particularly in grain, olive oil, and wine, played a crucial role in the Venetian economy. Under Venetian rule since 1217, the island was heavily fortified to protect maritime routes, but persistent local resistance, influenced by Byzantine traditions, led to frequent revolts. For the Sindici assigned to Crete, the island was the primary field of investigation. They were required to audit the several rectorates, oversee fiscal administration, examine complaints from local inhabitants, and ensure that communal resources had not been misused by Venetian officials.

Napoli di Romania (modern-day Nafplio) was a major Venetian stronghold in the Peloponnese in the early 15th century. Acquired by Venice in 1388 after periods of shifting Frankish and Byzantine control, the city became a key administrative and military center that anchored the Republic’s presence in the Argolic Gulf. For the Sindici operating in the region, Napoli di Romania served as a principal point of inquiry. They were required to review the conduct of local officials, scrutinize fiscal management, examine petitions and complaints from the inhabitants, and ensure the proper functioning of maritime defenses and commercial regulations.

Negroponte (modern-day Euboea) was one of the most important Venetian possessions in the Aegean during the early 15th century. Although the island had been fragmented among feudal lords after 1204, Venice progressively consolidated its authority, achieving full control in 1390. Chalcis, the island’s capital, developed into a major administrative and military center safeguarding the maritime routes between the Eastern Mediterranean and the Black Sea. In the commissio of 1408, Negroponte occupies a central logistical and administrative role: repeated instructions address the bailo, the captain, and the locally stationed galley, which was formally assigned to transport the Sindici between the various locations under inquiry. The Sindici were also ordered to collaborate closely with the local rectorate and to investigate fiscal, judicial, and military matters crucial to Venice’s hold over the region.

Canea (modern-day Chania), in the early 15th century, was an important Venetian port on the island of Crete, serving as a key commercial and military center in the eastern Mediterranean. It was the second most important city of the island after Candia. It was the final destination of the galley that transported the Sindici from Venice to Greece. The locality fell under the direct scrutiny of the Sindici of Crete.

div.head: Synopsis
div.p: This edition offers a scholarly treatment of the ducal commission of 1408 appointing four Sindici Inquisitori to audit governance and finances across key nodes of the Stato da Mar. It specifies jurisdiction, procedures for receiving complaints and evidence, powers over officials, and logistical provisions for travel, remuneration, and reporting to Venice. This edition provides a semi-diplomatic transcription of the ASVe witness, with parallel markup enabling future alignment with normalized and translated layers and designed to be read alongside a parallel Marciana witness; see ASVe and Marc..

Magistracies and offices: Doge di Venezia, Comune di Venezia, Consiglio dei Rogati, Zonta, Maggior Consiglio, Consiglio dei Quaranta, Avogadori di Comun, Ufficiali alle Cazude, Ufficiali alle Rason Vecchie, Consiglieri Ducali, Sindici Inquisitori, Rettori in Levante, Officiali in Levante, Consiglieri in Levante, Capitani in Levante, Bailo e Capitano di Negroponte, Consiglieri di Negroponte, Duca di Creta, Camera di Creta, Capitano del Golfo, Sopracomito, Capitani navali.
Persons cited: Michele Steno, Andrea Barbaro, Jacopo Michiel, Giovanni Emo, Luca Tron, Ludovico Morosini, Nicolò Venier, Francesco Leono, Pietro Gradenigo.
Places: Venice, Doge’s Palace, Corfu, Modon, Coron, Crete, Napoli of Romania, Negroponte, Chania.

Structure: Chapters encoded as div (type=chapter) with pointers between witnesses (e.g., ASVe I ↔ Marc. I), original layout with pb/lb, and entity markup (persName, placeName, orgName, term) for authority control.

list.item: Base text: The edition adopts the witness preserved in the Archivio di Stato di Venezia (ASVe) as the base text, owing to its completeness, archival provenance, and formal ducal-chancery subscription. The Marciana witness (Marciana) was independently transcribed and collated. Earlier partial transcriptions include Hopf 1873 and Noiret 1892. This is the first edition to collate both surviving original witnesses.

Orthography & punctuation: Chancery Latin spelling of the early 15th century is preserved. Punctuation has been lightly regularised to improve readability. Scribal abbreviations and suspensions are silently expanded following the principles defined in editorialDecl.

Structure & layout: Chapter divisions (div), page breaks (pb), and line breaks (lb) reproduce the manuscript segmentation. Where possible, facs links each pb to a manuscript image. Marginal or interlinear additions are encoded with add, deletions with del.

Textual variation and apparatus: A selective critical apparatus records meaningful textual variation between the ASVe and Marciana witnesses. Variants are encoded using the app element, with the ASVe reading treated as lem and the Marciana reading as rdg. Apparatus entries are classified according to the nature of the variation, as follows:
app type="grammatical": grammatical or syntactic variation involving agreement, case, number, person, verbal form, or constructional rephrasing without a change in semantic content (e.g. habeatis terminum / datum terminum, vobis / tibi).
app type="lexical": substantive lexical or phrasal variation, including the addition or omission of lexical material and reformulations that affect the explicitness or semantic scope of a passage (e.g. refutare / ipsum sindacatum refutare).
app type="numerical": variation in numerical expressions, including Roman numerals, spelled-out numerals, and quantitative values.
app type="omission": explicit additions or omissions of words or phrases between witnesses.
app type="orthographic": purely graphic or orthographic variation, including spelling differences, scribal errors, and variant written forms of the same word (e.g. delongatio / elongatio, furantum / furatum).
app type="paratext": paratextual or structural variation, such as headings, rubrics, titles, or other non-running-text elements.
app type="transposition": reordering of identical lexical material or syntactic constituents without semantic or grammatical alteration (e.g. libertatem plenam / plenam libertatem). Minor spelling variation, capitalization, and routine punctuation differences are not recorded. Apparatus encoding follows variantEncoding method="parallel-segmentation" and location="inline".
Numeric normalization: All numerical expressions are encoded with num and normalized in value. Medieval forms (Roman numerals, monetary sums, counts, dates) remain diplomatic in the text.
Dates and measures: Dates use date with normalised when. Measures and sums specify type (e.g. "currency", "time", "count"). No modern conversions are introduced.

Encoding rationale: Encoding aims to be descriptive rather than interpretative, representing observable textual or codicological features rather than conjectural readings, ensuring transparency and reproducibility.

div.head: I
div.p:
Nos Michael Steno, dei gratia dux venetiarum et cetera, committimus vobis nobilibus viris Andree Barbaro et Jacopo
Michael, Johanni Aymo et Luce Truno, dilectis civibus et fidelibus nostris, quod pro bono hortamine, salute et conservatione
locorum nostrorum Corphoy, Mothoni, Coroni , insule Crete, Neapolis Romanie et Nigropontis, et ut subditi et
fideles nostri illarum partium sentiant et videant dulcedinem et benignitatem nostram, et ad ipsorum statum pacificum
et tranquillum nos plurimum vigilare in nolendo aut permittendo quod aliquis subditus noster oblique vel indirecte tractetur
et contra debitum rationis de nostro mandato, vos Andreas Barbaro et Jacobus Michael ire debeatis in nostros sollemnes
provisores et sindicos ad partes antedictas eundo, solummodo per totam insulam Crete et conferendo cum ducha Identified as Ludovico Morosini, Duca di Creta (1407–1409).

div.head: II
div.p:
Vos autem Johannes Aymo et Lucas Truno ire debeatis in nostros sollemnes provisores et sindicos ad dictas partes eundo
solummodo ad partes Corphoy, Mothoni, Coroni, Neapolis Romanie et Nigropontis, incipiendo in illo loco
qui vobis magis comodus et utilis apparebit, in quibus et quolibus eorum audiatis, observetis et faciatis in
omnibus et per omnia, ut de insula Crete superius dictum est et commissum aliis sociis vestris.

div.head: III
div.p:
Verum si vos ituri in Cretam eritis expediti de factis vobis commissis, et in redditu vestro reperietis vos in
partibus Coroni et Mothoni vel in aliis partibus, in quibus alii sotii vestri non sindicassent, possitis
etiam et debeatis pro celleri expeditione inquirere et examinare et sindicare, ut potestis de aliis vobis commissis.
Et si vos omnes quatuor eritis simul, debeatis facere et exercere insimul officium vestrum.

div.head: IIII
div.p:
Omnes querelas autem cuiscumque condictionis existant, testificationes et probationes per modum predictum, quas conque
rentes ipsi volent producere, faciatis ordinate poni in scriptis, observando modum in inquisitionibus et querelis,
quem faciunt et observant nostri advocatores comunis in Venetiis, non impediendo seu intromittendo vos de regimi
nibus presentibus, sed de regiminibus preteritis inquiratis diligenter et bene secundum formam huius vestre comissionis.
Et omnia que examinaveritis et feceritis tenemini ordinate in redditu vestro portare Venetias, et cum appli
cueritis Venecias omnino infra unum annum expedivisse et placitasse in nostris consiliis ordinatis sicut faciunt
et facere possunt advocatores comunis, omnia intromissa per vos, salvis de illis nostris rectoribus et officialibus, qui
se reperirent in regiminibus vel officiis in quibus essent. Et ut dicti tales non possint se excusare, tene
mini dictis rectoribus et officialibus vestris literis significare et committere, quod debeant completo termino vel officio
suo directe venire vel mittere Venetias suum procuratorem legitimum ad deffendendum iura sua, alioquin procederetis,
eorum aliqua sua in aliquo absentia non obstante habendo medietatem condemnationum que fient. Et si qua restarent ad
expediendum post complementum dictorum terminorum, teneamini et debeatis omnes scripturas et omnes alios actus et proces
sus acceptos et formatos per vos videlicet quaslibet per se presentare et dare nostris advocatoribus comunis, ut loco
vestro facere possint officum predictum. Et dicti advocatores comunis teneantur omnino ipsas omnes scripturas
sibi presentatas videlicet a die presentationis usque sex menses expedivisse pro posse suo secundum eorum bonam conscientiam
et sub debito sacramenti.

div.head: V
div.p:
Insuper tenemini, cum applicueritis Venetias, infra unum mensem legisse et dedisse in scriptis omnes
scripturas, actus et processus acceptos et formatas formatos per vos, salvis nominibus accusatorum, nostro ducali dominio,
ut semper sit informatum de eo quod ducetis et de eo quod restabit ad ducendum. Et hoc sub pena librarum
centum
C
pro quolibet vestrum in vestris perperis bonis, et similiter teneamini, postquam redieritis Venecias,
infra terminum trium mensium dedisse in scriptis illos quos intromiseritis, eorum capitula et alias scrip
turas solitas dari, et hoc sub pena librarum
centum
C
cuilibet vestrum pro quolibet intromisso, cui non daretis
dicta capitula et alias scripturas.

div.head: VI
div.p:
Insuper non potestis, postquam redieritis a dicto sindicatu, eligi ad aliquam aliam rem extra civitatem et corpus
venetiarum usque ad unum annum, sed ad officia et regimina de intus corpus venetiarum sic. Et
nichilominus remanere debeatis in dicto sindicatu, non obstante quod sitis offitiales. Et non potestis
etiam postquam redieritis a dicto sindicatu refutare ipsum sindacatum refutare modo aliquo a die applica
tionis usque unum annum, sub pena ducatorum centum auri pro quolibet.

div.head: VII
div.p:
Insuper, quia per ultimos sindicos et provisores nostros destinatos ad dictas partes Levantis formati
fuerunt aliqui processus et accepte nonnulle testificationes quas omnes assignaverunt nostris advocatoribus
comunis et sic remanent suspense, et utile sit quod omnes tractentur equaliter committimus vobis
quod accipere debeatis a dictis nostris om.
advocatoribus comunis, omnes scripturas eis presentatas per ipsos sindicos,
et ipsas portare vobiscum, ut si vobis videbitur super ipsis de novo accipere alias testificationes
et formare alios actus, possitis facere ut potestis de aliis vobis commissis. Et sic teneantur
dicti advocatores, eas vobis dare et assignare.

div.head: VIII
div.p:
Et ducale dominium teneatur, pro expeditione predictorum, tam vobis provisoribus quam advocatoribus comunis
dare consilium et consilia que volueritis et volent, sub pena librarum
decem
X
pro quolibet consiliario qui de
negaret et qualibet vice.

div.head: VIIII
div.p:
De quibus omnibus suprascriptis penis vel aliqua earum non possit modo aliquo fieri alicui contrafacienti
gratia, donum, remissio, recompensatio, termini elongatio vel aliqua declaratio, sub pena librarum VC
pro quolibet consiliario, capiente capite , sapiente, vel alio ponente vel consentiente partem in contrarium. Et pre
dicta commissa sint nostris officialibus de catavere, qui inquirere et exigere debeant dictas penas, ha
bendo partem ut de aliis sui officii. Et si consilium om. est contra et cettera.

div.head: X
div.p:
Insuper, quia in locis nostris Crete, Coroni et Mothoni ac aliorum locorum nostrorum predictorum a bono tempore
citra alique rationes frumenti et aliorum bladorum ac quamplurium aliarum rerum et diversarum nostri comunis non
fuerunt vise et examinate, et sit utile pro bono et utilitate nostri comunis, quod generaliter omnes rationes
nostri comunis, non specificando aliquod tempus, per vos videantur et examinentur, committimus vobis,
quod debeatis generaliter videre et diligenter examinare omnes rationes frumenti et aliorum bladiorum ac om
nium aliarum rerum spectantium nostro comuni, cuiuscumque condictionis existant, et de quocumque tempore, ut vobis
videbitur fore necesse, habendo super hoc illammet libertatem quam habetis de aliis vobis commissis.

div.head: XI
div.p:
Insuper debeatis inquirere, si damna et extorsiones facte sint per dictos rectores et offitiales contra
nostrum comune, cum illa libertate et modis omnibus quos habetis de aliis vobis commissis

div.head: XII
div.p:
Ceterum reperiendo aliquem in culpa qui foret in partibus illis, habeatis
libertatem plenam plenam libertatem imponendi
sibi penam quod personaliter veniat Venetias vel mittat commissionem ad personam, que possit et debeat ipsa uti,
taliter quod sufficiens sit responsator ad consequendam intentionem dominii. Et vos notificare ei debeatis
capitula, super quibus debeant fieri comissiones ad respondendum. Verum si aliquis officialis comisisset
tale quid et sic enorme quod suspicaremini quod non veniret Venetias, iuxta preceptum sibi factum per
vos propter gravitatem delicti, tunc in isto casu vos provisores et rector loci, existente ipso
rectore de ipsa opinione vobiscum, possitis ipsum offitialem facere personaliter detineri et mitti Venetias,
sicut vestre discretioni videbitur considerata culpa sua.

div.head: XIII
div.p:
Insuper, quia fertur quod in insula Crete et aliis partibus Romanie facta fuit et fit mala admi
nistratio bonorum et pecunie nostri comunis, habeatis libertatem plenariam inquirendi et examinandi ac dili
genter investigandi, tam per viam inquisitionis quam per testificationes, querelas et scripturas contra omnes,
qui viderentur vobis suspecti et male administrasse bona et pecuniam nostri comunis, videlicet ab annis
decem
X
citra. Et omnes tales quos culpabiles inveniretis, condemnare et compellere
possitis om. ad restituen
dum totum illud quod cognoveritis illos indebite administrasse et male accepisse, per illum modum
et cum illa libertate plenaria, quam habent et servant officiales rationum veterum in Venetiis contra male
administrantes bona et havere comunis, ita quod in isto casu sitis offitiales rationum. Et de toto eo quod
exegeritis habere, debeatis medietatem, et scribatis et mandetis regiminibus Crete et aliorum locorum predictorum
quod dare debeant vobis auxilium et favorem, tam de notariis quam de omnibus aliis, quotiens ab eis
requisiveritis illud pro dicta executione, contra quoslibet per vos condemnatos facienda. Quam executio
nem si complere non poteritis ante discessum vestrum de partibus in quibus fueritis, committere debeatis
illam faciendam rectoribus locorum, ubi illam complere non poteritis. Quibus rectoribus commisimus
et efficaciter mandavimus, sicut sibi commiseritis verum si condemnati per vos de condemnationibus quas
feceritis contra eos conqueri voluerint, habeant libertatem recurendi ad nostrum ducale dominium vel ad
alia loca ad que recurere possunt illi, qui volunt conqueri de offitialibus rationum, et persequi
jus suum contra vos provisores et sindicos. Et si fueritis male condemnasse convicti et a condemnatis
exegisse, debeatis totum quod exegeritis et habueritis restituere et medietatem plus pro pena.

div.head: XIIII
div.p:
Item habere debeatis de salario pro primis quatuor mensibus ducatos CLX auri pro quolibet,
et abinde in antea ducatos XX auri pro quolibet in mense. De quibus ducatis CLX vos
duo sindici, qui estis ituri in Cretam, habere debetis, hic in Venetiis ante recessum vestrum,
ducatos centum auri, et alios ducatos LX habere debetis a camera nostra Crete, et
similiter alios ducatos XX in mense pro illo tempore quo steteritis extra in dicto sindicatu, ultra dictos
quatuor
IIII
menses. Et sic scribimus et mandamus regimini Crete, quod deinde vobis faciat
solutionem predictam. Vos autem sindici qui ibitis ad partes Nigropontis et Romanie habere
debetis totum vestrum salarium predictum hic in Venetiis. Et insuper de toto eo quod intromittetis
et condemnationem et sententiam facietis habere debeatis medietatem. Et potestis expendere vos sindici
ituri in Cretam inter vos ambos ducatos duos auri in die, ducendo vobiscum famulos
duos pro quolibet, unum notarium cum uno famulo, et unum quocum coquum . Et similiter vos
alii duo ituri ad partes Nigropontis et ad alias partes potestis expendere alios ducatos
duos auri in die, ducendo vobiscum similem familiam, non computatis in his nabulis navigiorum
et agociis equorum. Et debetis esse ad unum denarium de omnibus his, de quibus concurretis
in una opinione.

div.head: XV
div.p:
Et si feceritis aliquam inquisitionem contra aliquem, qui esset extra illum locum, ubi illam fe
ceritis, habeatis libertatem, postquam applicueritis Venetias, faciendi officium vobis commissum per
modum supradictum contra illum, contra quem inquisiveritis, usque terminum vobis superius limitatum,
ita quod teneamini et debeatis vos expedivisse per totum dictum tempus.

div.head: XVI
div.p:
Insuper, declaramus vobis, quod in casu quo in aliquo essetis differentes, quod quilibet vestrum
habeat libertatem plenariam inquirendi et intromittendi, prout possetis, si essetis
concordes.

div.head: XVII
div.p:
Quia per Added above the line, indicated by a reference mark. suprascriptam partem de inquirendo contra illos, qui male administrassent pecuniam comunis, non
videtur vos provisores et sindicos habere libertatem in aliquo casu inquirendi contra aliquam spetialem
personam, et sicut fertur publice, aliqui cives et habitatores ipsorum locorum Romanie pro necessitatibus
arduis et magnis nostri comunis in partibus illis mutuaverint multam pecunie quantitatem recto
ribus nostris, nomine nostri comunis pro furniendo et solvendo ubi extiterat oportunum, quam pecuniam
non valentes rehabere aliquo modo, in totum nec in partem, fecerunt venditionem de ipsa pecu
nia vel denariis forte pro medietate vel minori quantitate aliquibus ementibus, quibus emptoribus
statim fuit solutum de bonis denariis integraliter pro tota quantitate dictorum denariorum seu pe
cunie nostro comuni mutuate, quod fuit cum damno maximo nostri comunis, quia dicti emptores nichil
de bursa sua solverunt, nec aliquid mutuaverunt comuni, et tamen lucrati fuerunt medietatem
propter quod solvi non potuit nec dari ubi magis necessarium erat dari et solvi, sicut erant soldati,
qui compleverant pagas suas per longum tempus, et alie res multum opportune cum maximo
periculo status nostri, capta fuit pars, quod committatur vobis provisoribus et sindicis quod quando
eritis in partibus Romanie, debeatis diligenter inquirere et examinare contra omnem personam, quam
senseritis talia mercata fecisse, per modum predictum. Et quos inveneritis emisse de talibus
denariis et pecunia ac lucratos fuisse ut supra dicitur, faciatis totum illud lucrum, quod ex inde
percepissent, restitui et poni in nostrum comune. Verum, ut vos provisores et sindici sitis magis soliciti ad inquirendum
de predictis mercatis et lucris, habere debeatis, de toto eo quod inveneritis et poni feceritis in comune, soldos duos
pro libra. Et, si vobis sindicis et provisoribus constaverit aliquem rectorem vel officialem nostrum fuisse participem
talis emptionis vel lucri, procedere debeatis contra eum vel eos, sicut in parte de male administrantibus pecu
niam comunis
plenius continetur, vobis commissa in illa parte, videlicet que tetigisset illum rectorem vel offi
cialem de dicta emptione vel lucro solum vobis commissa plenius continetur, in illa videlicet parte, que tetigisset illum rectorem vel officialem de dicta emptione vel lucro solum . Et si de predictis vel aliquo predictorum fuerit accusator per
quem veritas habeatur, habere debeat soldos duos pro libra de parte tangente comuni, et teneatur de cre
dentia, quam partem, ut dictum est, superius debeatis inviolabiliter observare.

div.head: XVIII
div.p:
Et non potestis refutare, sub pena ducatorum centum auri pro quolibet. Et debeatis omnino recedere
cum illa galeota, quam mittimus Caneam. Et cum applicueritis Mothonum, vos Johannes Aymo et Lucas
Truno, qui vaditis Nigropontem, ascendetis super galea Nigropontis ventura Mothonum ad levandum no
bilem virum ser Nicolaum Venerio, qui vadit baiulus et capitaneus NigropontisSon of Sergio Venier, Bailo e Capitano di Negroponte (1407–1409)., vos vero Andreas
Barbaro et Jaccopus Michael ire debeatis cum dicta galeota usque ad partes Crete.

div.head: XVIIII
div.p:
Insuper, licet per suprascripta capitula sit vobis data libertas inquirendi contra omnes generaliter, qui essent vel fuissent
in partibus et locis supranotatis ab annis decem citra, tamen vos avisamus, quod sicut captum est in nostris
consiliis rogatorum et addicionis non potestis vos impedire de illis processibus, qui iam forent abinati et intro
missi per advocatores nostri comunis, qui advocatores tenentur dictos tales processus intromissos dare vobis
in scriptis, ut sciatis, quid debeatis observare.

div.head: XX
div.p:
Item tenemini et debetis pro possendo melius habere informationem et veritatem rerum, que non forent bene
facte per rectores et officiales nostros dictarum partium, convocare et interrogare separatim de nostris fidelibus dictorum
locorum usque ad numerum XII ad minus pro quolibet locorum, tam grecis quam latinis et plures si vobis vide
buntur et illas personas que vobis videbuntur, et dare eis et cuilibet ipsorum sacramentum, quod dicant
et propalent omnia, que sciverint vel audiverint esse acta per aliquem rectorem vel officialem loci
unde erunt contra honorem nostrum et contra jus et justiciam, vel in damnum nostri comunis vel alicuius persone indebite
et iniuste, ut vos clarius possitis procedere et facere officium vestrum secundum formam vestre
commissionis.

div.head: XXI
div.p:
Item sciatis, quod de aliqua condemnatione vel sententia, que fiet per placitare vestrum vel alicuius vestrum,
non potest fieri aliqua gratia, donum, remissio, recompensatio, termini elongatio vel aliqua declaratio,
nisi per sex consiliarios, tria capita de XL, XXXV de XL, et tres partes maioris consilii consilii maioris .

div.head: XXII
div.p:
Insuper pro transitu vestrum de uno loco ad alium, scribimus per nostras litteras baiulo et capitaneo Nigropontis
et consiliariis Identified as Francesco Leono and Pietro Gradenigo, Consiglieri di Negroponte. suis, quod ad omnem requisitionem vestram om. mittere debeant galeam Nigropontis vel aliud sufficiens
et tutum navigium in omnem partem, ubi fueritis, ad levandum et conducendum vos Nigropontem. Et similiter,
existentibus vobis in Nigroponte, dictam galeam existentem armatam vel aliud sufficiens et securum navigium
vobis consignari faciat dictum regimen, pro passagio vestro, intelligendo quod dicta galea Nigropontis sit
solum pro sindicis Nigropontis et aliorum locorum Romanie, et non pro sindicis Crete. Et insuper
scribimus dicto regimini Nigropontis ac aliis rectoribus partium Romanie quod debeant vobis
de pecuniis neccessariis pro expensis vestris et familie vestre vobis subvenire, sicut ab eis duxe
ritis requirendum.

div.head: XXIII
div.p:
Et similiter scribimus capitaneo et supracomitis nostris Culphy et aliis capitaneis nostrorum
navigiorum armatorum, quod in casu quo se reperirent in illis partibus insule Crete vel Romanie vel aliis
ibi prope et fuerint requisiti tam a vobis sindicis Crete quam a vobis sindicis
Nigropontis et Romanie Romanie et Nigropontis
tam oretenus quam per literas, quod cum una ex dictis galeis vel navigiis vos levare et conducere debeant
ad aliquas partes, ipsi debeant vos levare et conducere prout duxeritis ordinandum, pro celleri expeditione
agendorum vobis commissorum, dummodo non essent aliis dummodo non essent aliis om. rebus maioribus agendis occupati nostris maioribus agendis occupati. Et tunc quando
non possitis per dictum modum habere passagium, vos providere debeatis de transitu vestro, prout vobis
melius videbitur, et cum quam minori expensa poteritis nostri comunis.

div.head: XXIIII
div.p:
Insuper capta fuit in consilio rogatorum et addicione pars infrascripti tenoris, videlicet om. cum sint multa loca,
territoria et possessiones nostri comunis, que debent incantari et deliverari in insula Crete, de quibus est utile
providere, ita quod non decipiatur comune nostrum, vadit pars, quod stringatur et prohibeatur, quod cancelarii, scribe
vel notarii camerariorum Crete vel alii pro eis vel eorum nomine non possint de cetero accipere ad incantum,
ullo modo, de illis territoriis et locis vel possessionibus nostri comunis, sub pena perdendi totum quod acciperent,
quod sit nostri comunis. Et scribatur duche et consiliariis Crete et addatur in suis commissionibus, quod
sic teneatur et debeant observare et facere observari.

div.head: XXV
div.p:
Item commissum est dictis duche et consiliariis Crete quod debeant facere solvi de presenti totum et
quicquid predicti cancellarii, notarii aut scribe tenentur solvere nostro comuni, occaxione ter
renorum, locorum et possessionum, quas habuissent a nostro comuni, intromittendo et vendendo de bonis illorum si non
solvent ut dictum est, quam partem vos sindici et provisores similiter observari facere debeatis.

div.head: XXVI
div.p:
Si convictus fueris per advocatores comunis quod furatus fueris de bonis et havere comunis libras L ad grossos
vel inde supra, aut acceperis ab aliis contra commissionem tuam libras C ad grossos vel inde supra, modo aliquo
vel ingenio, intelligaris ex nunc cecidisse ad solvendum capitale et tantumdem, pro pena, usque ad tres
dies postquam fueris convictus, sub pena soldorum quinque pro libra tam capitalis quam pene. Que pena
dividatur per medium, videlicet medietas sit advocatorum et alia medietas sit comunis. Et si fuerit accusator,
pena dividatur per tertium et sit de credentia, et ultra hoc sis perpetuo privatus omnibus officiis,
regiminibus, consiliis et beneficiis comunis venetiarum, tam intus quam extra, et crideris in primo maiori consilio
de festo solenni cridato vel in quo fiant de XII duodecim regiminibus per unum ex advocatoribus comunis. Verum, si vo
les restituere et restitues usque ad tres dies postquam fueris requisitus ab advocatoribus, non permittendo
te convinci sed confitendo te furatum fuisse de bonis comunis vel accepisse ab aliis contra commissionem tuam,
tunc tenearis solvere capitale et medietatem plus pro pena, que dividatur ut supra. Et ultra
hoc sis perpetuo privatus hoc presenti regimine, et crideris in maioris consilio ut est dictum. Si vero
convictus fueris furtum furatum fuisse a libris L infra de bonis comunis vel accepisse ab aliis aliter accepisse ab aliis contra commis
sionem tuam a libris C ad grossos infra, tunc incurras ad solvendum capitale et medietatem plus
pro pena ad dictum terminum et sub dicta pena, que dividatur ut supra. Et ultra hoc sis perpetuo
privatus hoc regimine et publiceris in maiori consilio per advocatores comunis, ut est dictum. Et
si voles restituere et restitues usque ad tres dies postquam fueris requisitus ab advocatoribus comunis, non
permittendo te convinci sed confitendo te furantum furatum fuisse de bonis comunis a libris L infra ad grossos, tunc ad
dictum terminum et sub dicta pena teneris solvere capitale et tertium plus pro pena, que dividatur
ut supra; et ultra hoc priveris hoc presenti regimine. Verum si scriberes in tuis rationibus
vel quaternis aliquas expensas vel alias res, quas officiales rationum dicerent non potuisse poni,
tunc hoc non habeatur pro furto sed veniatur ad collegium nostri consiliariorum, capitum, advocatorum
et officialium rationum, ubi terminetur si dicte expense erunt bene posite vel non, sicut modo servatur
et sicut continetur in capitulari consilariorum in hac parte. Sed si vigore alicuius sententie, determinatio
nis vel alterius actus iudiciarii aut vigore alicuius publice consuetudinis aliquid acciperes
vel dares contra id quod deberes, quod forte crederes posse licite accipere vel dare, in his casibus
non cadas ad dictas penas, sed servetur illud quod servatur hodie, videlicet quod si volueris restituere
et restitues quod indebite acceperis infra tres dies, ipsum restituas sine aliqua pena. Si autem
permiseris te duci et convinci ad consilia, cadas ad dictam penam dupli, que dividatur sicut
dividitur hodie. Et de omnibus dictis penis vel capitalibus non potest tibi fieri gratia, donum,
remissio, revocatio vel termini delongatio elongatio , sub pena ducatorum VC
partem in contrarium.

div.head: XXVII
div.p:
In redditu vestro, postquam applicueritis Venetias, tenemini infra unum mensem ire vel mittere
ad officiales rationum ad faciendum rationem cum eis et ad solvendum illud quod debebitis dare et refundere
nostro comuni, pro familia et equis qui vobis defecerint deffecissent , tempore vestri regiminis, in ratione grossorum trium in
die pro quolibet ente de vestra familia et pro quolibet equo qui vobis defecissent, pro tanto tempore quanto
vobis defecerint. Verum, si deficiet vobis aliquis de vestra familia, habeatis terminum ad remittendum alium datum terminum ad remittendum alium
octo dierum. Et si aliquis equus vobis defecerit, habeatis terminum ad remittendum alium duodecim
dierum. Et si remiseritis ad dictos terminos, nichil teneamini refundere comuni pro eis; si autem non
remiseritis ad terminos antedictos, tunc debeatis refundere comuni a die, qua vobis defecerint, usque
ad diem quo remiseritis in ratione predicta. Hoc autem servabitis sub pena librarum quingentarum,
et tamen tenemini ad solvendum omne id quod debebitis pro dictis deffectibus, in ratione predicta.
Cuius pene librarum VC medietas sit accusatoris si fuerit per quem sciatur veritas, et alia medietas
dividatur inter comune nostrum et officiales rationum predictos. Et si condemnabimini per
officiales rationum ad aliquid dandum vel refundendum, tunc subiaceatis parti capte in maiori
consilio contra illos qui non solvunt, postquam eis preceptum fuerit per officiales rationum predictos.

div.head: XXVIII
div.p:
Insuper, observare debeatis infrascriptam partem captam in nostris consiliis rogatorum et additionis, videlicet,
quia bonum est declarare libertatem, quam sindici et provisores nostri ituri in Cretam et alia loca
Romanie habere debent prout soliti sunt habere, super factis pro quibus facti sunt provisores, ordi
netur quod et quando dicti sindici et provisores erunt in locis nostris insule Crete, Coroni et Mothoni,
Corphoy, Neapolis Romanie et Nigropontis debeant esse et conferre cum rectoribus ipsorum
locorum, et secum inquirere et diligenter examinare de omnibus que sibi videbuntur esse utilia ac ne
cessaria pro bono commodo ac conservatione ipsorum locorum. Et facta diligenti examinatione, debeant
requirere ipsos rectores quod poni faciant suas opiniones et consilium in scriptis, quas suis literis
inclusas debeant Venetias apportare et nobis presentare. Verum sit licitum dictis sindicis et
cuilibet eorum venire postea ad consilium rogatorum et additionis infra duos menses, post adventum
suum Venetias, et consulere et ponere partem super omnibus, que videbuntur eis vel alicui eorum
comoda et neccessaria pro bono, conservatione et utilitate locorum predictorum. Et si erit de consilio possit ponere balotam sicut de conselio possit ponere ballotam . Et ultra predicam generalem libertatem, si placebit dominio aliquid specifi
care dictis sindicis super quo dicti sindici et provisores habere debeant advertentiam et examinationem,
ponatur specialiter in commissione dictorum sindicorum, non derogando propterea quod ultra que spetialiter
commissa eis fuerint examinanda, possint generaliter examinare et providere ut superius dictum est.

Iurastis proficuum et honorem comunis venetiarum, eundo stando et redeundo om. et cetera .
Omnia que vobis tibi dicendo mandabimus, attendes et observabis bona fide sine fraude.
Datum in nostro ducali palatio, die

div.head: TEI-XML encoding of the ducal commission issued in 1408 in the name of Doge Michele Steno, based on the manuscript preserved in the Biblioteca Nazionale Marciana.

div.p:
Commissio egregiorum et nobilium virorum dominorum Johannis
Aymo et Luce Truno, honorabilium sindicorum ad partes
Romanie.

div.head: I
div.p:
Nos Michael Steno, dei gratia dux veneciarum et cetera, committimus vobis nobilibus viris
Andree Barbaro et Jacobo Michael et Johanni Aymo et Luce Truno, civibus et fidelibus
nostris quod pro bono ortamine, salute et conservatione locorum nostrorum Corphoy, Mothoni, Co
roni, insule Crete, Neapolis Romanie et Nigropontis, et ut subditi et fideles nostri
illarum partium sentiant et videant dulcedinem et benignitatem nostram, et ad ipsorum statum
pacificum et tranquillum nos plurimum vigilare in nolendo aut permittendo quod aliquis
subditus noster oblique vel indirecte tractetur et contra debitum rationis de nostro
mandato, vos Andreas Barbaro et Jacobus Michael ire debeatis in nostros sollemnes pro
visores et sindicos ad partes antedictas eundo, solummodo per totam insulam Crete et
conferendo cum ducha, consiliariis et capitaneo nostris Crete et aliis nostris rectoribus dicte
insule, cum quibus, habita collatione insimul quando vobis utile apparebit, fatiatis
publice proclamari quod omnes volentes conqueri et gravare se de extorsionibus aliquibus
gravaminibus et violentiis vel aliis insolenciis seu malis, que quomodolibet re
cepissent a rectoribus vel officialibus nostris, qui in partibus illis extitissent a X annis
citra, debeant comparere coram vobis ad deponendum querelas suas ordinate et ad
dandum et producendum testificationes, probationes et oppositiones suas, assignando eis
illum terminum vel illos terminos super hoc quos videbitis competentes, verum tamen relinquimus
in libertate vestra incipiendum illa terra, loco sive castro prout vobis melius et utilius
apparebit.

div.head: II
div.p:
Vos autem Johannes Aymo et Lucas Truno ire debeatis in nostros sollemnes provisores
et sindicos ad dictas partes eundo solummodo ad partes Corphoy, Mothoni, Coroni, Neapolis
Romanie et Nigropontis, incipiendo in illo loco qui vobis magis comodus et utilis apparebit,
in quibus et quolibet eorum audiatis, observetis et faciatis in omnibus et per omnia, ut de insula
Crete superius dictum est, et commissum aliis sociis vestris.

div.head: III
div.p:
Verum si vos ituri in Cretam eritis expediti de factis vobis commissis, et in reditu vestro
reperietis vos in partibus Coroni et Mothoni, vel in aliis partibus, in quibus alii sotii vestri
non sindicassent, possitis etiam et debeatis pro celeri expeditione inquirere et examinare
et sindicare, ut potestis de aliis vobis commissis. Et si vos omnes quatuor eritis simul,
debeatis facere et exercere insimul offitium vestrum.

div.head: IIII
div.p:
Omnes querelas autem cuiuscunque conditionis existant, testificationes et probationes per
modum predictum, quas conquerentes ipsi volent producere, fatiatis ordinate poni in scriptis,
observando modum in inquisitionibus et querelis, quem faciunt et observant nostri advocatores
comunis in Venetiis, non impediendo seu intromittendo vos de regiminibus presentibus, sed de regiminibus
preteritis inquiratis diligenter et bene secundum formam huius vestre commissionis. Et omnia
que examinaveritis et feceritis tenemini ordinate in reditu vestro portare Venetias, et cum
applicueritis Venetias omnino infra unum annum expedivisse, placitasse in nostris consiliis ordinatis
sicut fatiunt et facere possunt advocatores comunis, omnia intromissa per vos, salvis de illis nostris
rectoribus et officialibus, qui se reperirent in regiminibus vel officiis, in quibus essent. Et ut
dicti tales non possint se excusare, tenemini dictis rectoribus et offitialibus vestris literis signi
ficare et committere, quod debeant completo termino vel officio suo directe venire vel mittere Ve
necias suum procuratorem legitimum ad defendendum iura sua, alioquin procederetis, eorum absentia
in aliquo non obstante, habendo medietatem condenationum que fient. Et si qua restarent ad ex
pediendum post complementum dictorum terminorum, et teneamini et debeatis omnes scripturas et omnes
alios actus et processus acceptos et formatos per vos videlicet quaslibet per se presentare et dare nostris
advocatoribus comunis, ut loco vestro facere possint offitium predictum. Et dicti advocatores comunis
teneantur omnino ipsas omnes sibi presentatas videlicet a die presentationis usque sex menses expedivisse
pro posse suo secundum eorum bonam conscientiam et sub debito sacramenti.

div.head: V
div.p:
Insuper tenemini, cum applicueritis Venetias, infra unum mensem legisse et dedisse in scriptis omnes
scripturas, actus et processus acceptos et formatos per vos, salvis nominibus accusatorum,
nostro ducali dominio, ut semper sit informatum de eo quod ducetis et de eo quod restabit ad du
cendum. Et hoc sub pena librarum C pro quolibet vestrum in vestris perperis bonis, et simili
ter teneamini, postquam redieritis Venecias infra terminum trium mensium, dedisse in scriptis illos quos
intromisseritis, eorum capitula et alias scripturas solitas dari, et hoc sub pena librarum C cuilibet
vestrum pro quolibet intromisso, cui non daretis dicta capitula et alias scripturas.

div.head: VI
div.p:
Insuper non potestis, postquam redieritis a dicto sindacatu, eligi ad aliquam aliam rem extra civitatem
et corpus venetiarum usque ad unum annum, sed ad offitia et regimina de intus corpus venetiarum sic. Et nichi
lominus remanere debeatis in dicto sindacatu, non obstante quod sitis offitiales. Et non potestis
etiam postquam redieritis a dicto sindacatu ipsum sindacatum refutare modo aliquo a die applicationis
usque unum annum, sub pena ducatorum centum auri pro quolibet.

div.head: VII
div.p:
Insuper, quia per ultimos sindicos et provisores nostros destinatos ad dictas partes Levantis
formati fuerunt aliqui processus, et accepte nonnulle testificationes, quas omnes assignarunt
nostris advocatoribus comunis et sic remanent suspense, et utile sit quod omnes tractentur equaliter,
committimus vobis quod accipere debeatis a dictis advocatoribus comunis, omnes scripturas eis
presentatas per ipsos sindicos, et ipsas vobiscum portare, ut si vobis videbitur super ipsis de
novo accipere alias testificationes et formare alios actus, possitis facere, ut potestis de
aliis vobis commissis. Et sic teneantur dicti advocatores eas vobis dare et assignare.

div.head: VIII
div.p:
Et ducale dominium teneatur, pro expeditione predictorum, tam vobis provisoribus quam advocatoribus
comunis dare consilium et consilia que volueritis et volent, sub pena librarum X pro quolibet
consiliario qui denegaret et qualibet vice.

div.head: VIIII
div.p:
De quibus omnibus suprascriptis penis vel aliqua earum non possit modo aliquo fieri alicui contrafacienti
gratia, donum, remissio, recompensatio, termini elongatio, vel aliqua declaratio, sub pena librarum VC pro
quolibet consiliario, capite, sapiente, vel alio ponente vel consentiente partem in contrarium. Et predicta com
missa sint nostris officialibus de catavere, qui inquirere et exigere debeant dictas penas, habendo
partem ut de aliis sui officii. Et si consilium est contra et cetera.

div.head: X
div.p:
Insuper, quia in locis nostris Crete, Coroni et Mothoni ac aliorum locorum nostrorum predictorum a bono tempore
citra alique rationes frumenti et aliorum bladorum ac quamplurium aliarum rerum et diversarum
nostri comunis, non fuerunt vise et examinate, et sit utile pro bono et utilitate nostri comunis, quod generaliter
omnes rationes nostri comunis, non specificando aliquod tempus, per vos videantur et examinentur,
committimus vobis quod debeatis generaliter videre et diligenter examinare omnes rationes frumenti
et aliorum bladorum ac omnium aliarum rerum spectantium nostro comuni, cuiuscumque conditionis existant, et de
quocumque tempore, ut vobis videbitur fore necesse, habendo super hoc illammet libertatem
quam habetis de aliis vobis commissis.

Insuper debeatis inquirere, si damna et extorsiones facte sint per dictos rectores et offitiales
contra nostrum comune, cum illa libertate et modis omnibus quos habetis de aliis vobis commissis.

div.head: XII
div.p:
Ceterum reperiendo aliquem in culpa, qui foret in partibus illis, habeatis plenam libertatem
imponendi sibi penam, quod personaliter veniat Venetias vel mittat commissionem ad personam,
que possit et debeat ipsa uti, taliter quod sufficiens sit responsator ad consequendam intentionem
dominii. Et vos notificare ei debeatis capitula, super quibus debeant fieri commissiones ad respo
ndendum. Verum si aliquis offitialis commisisset tale quid et sic enorme quod suspicaremini,
quod non veniret Venetias, iuxta preceptum sibi factum per vos propter gravitatem delicti, tunc in
isto casu vos provisores et rector loci, existente ipso rectore de ipsa opinione vobiscum,
possitis ipsum offitialem facere personaliter detineri et mitti Venetias, sicut vestre discretioni
videbitur considerata culpa sua.

div.head: XIII
div.p:
Insuper, quia fertur quod in insula Crete et aliis partibus Romanie facta fuit et fit mala
administratio bonorum et pecunie nostri comunis, habeatis libertatem plenariam inquirendi et exa
minandi ac diligenter investigandi, tam per viam inquisitionis quam per testificationes, que
relas et scripturas contra omnes qui viderentur vobis suspecti et male administrasse
bona et pecuniam nostri comunis, videlicet ab annis X citra. Et omnes tales quos culpabiles inveni
retis, condemnare et compellere ad restituendum totum illud quod cognoveritis illos indebite ad
ministrasse et male accepisse, per illum modum et cum illa libertate plenaria, quam habent
et servant officiales rationum veterum in Venetiis, contra male administrantes bona et
havere comunis, ita quod in isto casu sitis offitiales rationum. Et de toto eo quod exegeritis habere,
debeatis medietatem, et scribatis et mandetis regiminibus Crete et aliorum locorum predictorum
quod dare debeant vobis auxilium et favorem, tam de notariis, quam de omnibus aliis, quotiens ab eis
requisiveritis illud pro dicta executione, contra quoslibet per vos condemnatos facienda. Quam execu
tionem, si complere non poteritis ante discessum vestrum de partibus in quibus fueritis, committere de
beatis illam faciendam rectoribus locorum, ubi illam complere non poteritis. Quibus rectoribus com
misimus et efficaciter mandavimus, sicut sibi commiseritis verum si condemnati per vos de condemna
tionibus quas feceritis contra eos conqueri voluerint, habeant libertatem recurendi ad
nostrum ducale dominium vel ad alia loca ad que recurrere possunt illi, qui volunt conqueri de offi
tialibus rationum, et persequi jus suum contra vos provisores et sindicos. Et si fueritis
convinti male condemnasse et a condemnatis exegisse, debeatis totum quod exegeritis et habueritis
restituere et medietatem plus pro pena.

div.head: XIIII
div.p:
Item habere debeatis de salario pro primis quatuor mensibus ducatos CLX auri pro quolibet, et ab
inde in antea ducatos XX auri pro quolibet in mense. De quibus ducatis CLX vos duo
sindici, qui estis ituri in Cretam, habere debeatis, hic in Venetiis, ante recessum vestrum, ducatos
centum auri, et alios ducatos LX habere debeatis a camera nostra Crete, et similiter alios
ducatos XX in mense pro illo tempore quo steteritis extra in dicto sindicatu ultra dictos IIII
menses. Et sic scribimus et mandamus regimini Crete, quod deinde vobis fatiat subventionem predictam.
Vos autem sindici qui ibitis ad partes Romanie et Nigropontis habere debeatis totum vestrum salarium
predictum hic in Venetiis. Et insuper de toto eo quod intromittetis et condemnationem et sentenciam
facietis habere debeatis medietatem. Et potestis expendere vos sindici ituri in Cretam inter vos
ambos ducatos duos auri in die, ducendo vobiscum duos famulos pro quolibet, unum nota
rium cum uno famulo, et unum coquum. Et similiter vos alii duo ituri ad partes Nigropontis
et ad alias partes, potestis expendere alios ducatos duos auri in die, ducendo vobiscum
similem familiam, non computatis in his nabulis navigiorum et agotiis equorum. Et debetis
esse ad unum denarium de omnibus his, de quibus concurretis in una opinione.

div.head: XV
div.p:
Et si feceritis aliquam inquisitionem contra aliquem, qui esset extra illum locum, ubi
illam feceritis, habeatis libertatem, postquam applicueritis Venetias, fatiendi officium vobis com
missum per modum supradictum, contra illum, contra quem inquisiveritis, usque terminum
vobis superius limitatum, ita quod teneamini et debeatis vos expedivisse per totum dictum
tempus.

div.head: XVI
div.p:
Insuper, declaramus vobis, quod in casu quo in aliquo essetis diferentes, quod quilibet vestrum
habeat libertatem plenariam inquirendi et intromittendi, prout possetis, si essetis concordes.

div.head: XVII
div.p:
Quia per suprascriptam partem de inquirendo contra illos, qui male administrassent
pecuniam comunis, non videtur vos provisores et sindicos habere libertatem in aliquo casu
inquirendi contra aliquam spetialem personam, et sicut fertur publice aliqui cives et habitatores ipsorum
locorum Romanie pro necessitatibus arduis et magnis nostri comunis in partibus illis mutuaverint
multam pecunie quantitatem rectoribus nostris, nomine nostri comunis pro furniendo et solvendo ubi extiterat
opportunum, quam pecuniam non valentes rehabere aliquo modo, in totum nec in partem, fecerunt
venditionem de ipsa pecunia vel denariis forte pro medietate vel minore quantitate aliquibus
ementibus, quibus emptoribus statim fuit solutum de bonis denariis integraliter pro tota quanti
tate dictorum denariorum seu pecunie nostro comuni mutuate, quod fuit cum damno maximo nostri comunis,
quia dicti emptores nichil de bursa sua solverunt, nec aliquid mutuaverunt comuni, et tamen
lucrati fuerunt medietatem propter quod solvi non potuit nec dari ubi magis necessarium erat
dari et solvi, sicut erant soldati, qui compleverant pagas suas per longum tempus, et alie
res multum opportune cum maximo periculo status nostri, capta fuit pars, quod committatur
vobis provisoribus et sindicis, quod quando eritis in partibus Romanie, debeatis diligenter inquirere
et examinare contra omnem personam, quam senseritis talia mercata fecisse, per modum predictum.
Et quos inveneritis emisse de talibus denariis et pecunia ac lucratos fuisse, ut supra
dicitur, faciatis totum lucrum, quod exinde percepissent, restitui et poni in nostrum comune.
Verum, ut vos provisores et sindici sitis magis soliciti ad inquirendum de predictis mercatis et lucris,
habere debeatis, de toto eo quod inveneritis et poni feceritis in comune, soldos duos pro libra. Et, si
vobis sindicis et provisoribus constaverit aliquem rectorem vel officialem nostrum fuisse participem
talis emptionis vel lucri, procedere debeatis contra eum vel eos, sicut in parte de male
administrantibus pecuniam comunis vobis commissa plenius continetur, in illa videlicet parte, que
tetigisset illum rectorem vel officialem de dicta emptione vel lucro solum. Et si de predictis vel
aliquo predictorum fuerit accusator per quem veritas habeatur, habere debeat soldos duos pro libra de parte tangente comuni,
et teneatur de credentia,
quam partem, ut
dictum est, superius debeatis
